Cox, J.L., Holden, J.M., and Sagovsky, R. 1987. Detection of postnatal depression: Development of the 10-item Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale. British Journal of Psychiatry 150:782–786
Queensland Health Department. Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale. http://www.health.qld.gov.au/maternity/docs/epds-combined.pdf
Beyond Blue. The Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale: A Health Professional's Guide, http://docent.gplearning.com.au/docent/cds/default_shared/GPEA/modules/g03/EPDS_GP.pdf

details.purpose:
To detect depression in women who are pregnant or have recently had a baby. Developed by Cox JL, Holden JM and Sagovsky R 1987 (See references).
Internationally, the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale (EPDS) is the most widely accepted screening instrument used in the perinatal period. The EPDS was designed to allow screening of postnatal depression in the primary care setting1. It excludes some symptoms that are common in the perinatal period (tiredness, sleep disturbance, irritability) that other depression instruments include, as such symptoms do not differentiate between depressed and non-depressed postnatal women.
The value of the EPDS lies in the fact that it is easy to complete, has been validated in relation to other standardized psychiatric measures and has been found to be acceptable to women who are asked to complete it. Its use provides women with the opportunity to discuss their feelings and enables health professionals to discreetly raise the issue of postnatal depression.
details.use:
As a screening instrument, the EPDS should only be used to assess a woman’s mood over the past seven (7) days. High scores do not themselves confirm a depressive illness and, similarly, some women who score below a set threshold might have depression. Thus, the EPDS does not provide a clinical diagnosis of depression and it should not be used as a substitute for full psychiatric assessment or clinical judgement. Importantly the EPDS cannot be used to predict whether or not a respondent will experience depression in the future - it can only be used to determine current mood.
There is consensus in the literature that women with scores consistently ≥13 have a 60-100% probability of meeting diagnostic criteria for depression.
details.misuse: Should not be used to assess depression in general population.

items.items: Edinburgh postnatal depression scale
The 10-question Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale (EPDS) is used to screen for pregnancy or postnatal depression by assessing how a women has been feeling over the past 7 days.
Event Series
@ internal @
Any Event
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Tree
@ internal @
I have been able to laugh and see the funny side of things
Item 1.
As much as I always could
Able to laugh as much as in the past.
Not quite so much now
Able to laugh but a little less than in the past.
Definitely not so much now
Laughing considerably less than in the past.
Not at all
Not able to laugh at all.
I have looked forward with enjoyment to things
Item 2.
As much as I ever did
Looking forward to things as much as in the past.
Rather less than I used to
Still looking forward to things but a little less than in the past.
Definitely less than I used to
Definitely looking forward to things less than in the past.
Hardly at all
Almost always not looking forward to things.
I have blamed myself unnecessarily when things went wrong
Item 3.
Display responses in reverse score order 3-0
Never
I do not blame myself unnecessarily.
Not very often
I hardly ever blame myself unnecessarily.
Yes, some of the time
I do sometimes blame myself unnecessarily.
Yes, most of the time
I almost always blame myself unnecessarily.
I have been worried and anxious for no good reason
Item 4.
No, not at all
I have not been worried or anxious unless there is good reason.
Hardly ever
I do get worried very occasionally when there is no good reason.
Yes, sometimes
I am definitely worried or anxious when there is no good reason but not often.
Yes, very often
I am worried or anxious for no good reason frequently.
I have felt scared or panicky for no very good reason
Item 5.
No, not at all
I do not get scared or panicky at all.
No, not much
I hardly ever get scared or panicky.
Yes, sometimes
Sometimes I do get scared or panicky.
Yes, quite a lot
I am scared or panicky quite often.
Things have been getting on top of me
Item 6.
Display responses in reverse score order 3-0
No, I have been coping as well as ever
Things do not get on top of me.
No, most of the time I have coped
I am coping most of the time.
Yes, sometimes I haven't been coping as well as usual
Sometimes things get on top of me and I am not coping.
Yes, most of the time I haven't been able to cope at all
Often things are getting on top of me and I am not coping at all.
I have been so unhappy that I have had difficulties sleeping
Item 7.
Display responses in reverse score order 3-0
No, not at all
Difficulty sleeping due to unhappiness has not been a problem.
Not very often
I have occasionally had difficulties sleeping because I have felt unhappy.
Yes, quite often
I have difficulties sleeping due to feeling unhappy quite frequently.
Yes, most of the time
Most of the time I am having difficulties sleeping due to unhappiness.
I have felt sad or miserable
Item 8.
Display responses in reverse score order 3-0
No, not at all
I am not sad or miserable at all.
Not very often
I am only occasionally sad or sad or miserable.
Yes, quite often
I am frequently sad or miserable.
Yes, most of the time
I am almost constantly sad or miserable.
I have been so unhappy that I have been crying
Item 9.
Display responses in reverse score order 3-0
No, never
I am not crying at all.
Only occasionally
Sometimes I cry because I have been very unhappy.
Yes, quite often
I am crying because I am so unhappy frequently.
Yes, most of the time
I am almost always crying because I am so unhappy.
The thought of harming myself has occurred to me
Item 10.
Display responses in reverse score order 3-0
Never
I do not have thoughts of harming myself.
Hardly ever
I have had thoughts of harming myself but only very occasionally.
Sometimes
I have had thoughts of harming myself from time to time.
Yes, quite often
I do have thoughts of harming myself quite frequently.
Total score
Total score for the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale.
